article.headline: EIA reports a third straight weekly decline in U.S. crude supplies
article.body: The Energy Information Administration reported Wednesday that U.S. crude inventories fell for a third straight week, down by 2 million barrels for the week ended Sept. 25. That compared with an average climb of 1.9 million barrels expected by analysts polled by S&P Global Platts, while the American Petroleum Institute on Tuesday had reported a fall of 831,000 barrels, according to sources. The EIA data also showed crude stocks at the Cushing, Okla., storage hub rose by 1.8 million barrels for the week. Gasoline supply, meanwhile, climbed by 700,000 barrels, while distillate stockpiles declined by 3.2 million barrels. The S&P Global Platts survey had shown expectations for supply declines of 1.3 million barrels for gasoline and 1.7 million barrels for distillates. November West Texas Intermediate crude CLX20, -1.62% was up 26 cents, or 0.7%, at $39.55 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices traded at $39.40 before the supply data.
